Dozens of looters were detained over several days and most appeared unaware of the value of what was in the museum, gleefully ransacking the gift shop. They thought that the museum shop was the museum, said Zahi Hawass , Egypt's top archaeologist. ''These people are ignorant, they are outlaws.'' Nine looters climbed the fire escape to the museum roof and lowered themselves on ropes from a glass pane

Egypt's leading archaeologists, Zahi Hawass , who has just accepted the post of minister of antiquities in Barack Obama Hosni Mubarak 's new cabinet, has praised the combined efforts of the security forces and Egyptians who confronted the looters: Today I can tell you that I'm so happy... to announce that everything is safe and nothing can happen in the future, because the police appeared today, and the army, and the Egyptian people together. What is unique, that all these people who tried to rob the antiquities were outlaws, criminals that came out of jail... and they began to attack the monuments. But who stood against them? The real Egyptians. If the Cairo museum is safe, Egypt will be safe. Omar Robert Hamilton tweets: ''It feels like the government has given up. Says Egypt's Hosni Mubarak Knows He's On the Way Out Defense Donald Rumsfeld said Egyptian President Bush Hosni Mubarak ''is behaving in a way that he understands that he will eventually depart'' and that the crisis in Egypt is probably best handled through private diplomacy. Donald Rumsfeld , who has known Hosni Mubarak since 1975, told ABC's Good Morning America that the United States' interest in Egypt should be focused on ''having that country evolve toward freer economic systems.''
